loans.use: to buy supplies for her business

loans.name: Harlen

texts.en:
Harlen R. lives in the village of Maribojoc, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 38 years old, married and has three young children. Harlen earns a living by running a general store where she sells items people in her community need and use daily. She has been in this line of work for 21 years, and earns about 20,000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Harlen joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid 10 previous loans from PMPC and has applied for a new one, for 50,000 PHP, to buy additional items to sell to her customers. She plans to use the additional income made possible by this loan to put money aside for future emergencies. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Matale Women's Group 2 - Lugazi

texts.en:
B. Mary is an upbeat, 26-year-old mother of two kids. She eagerly agrees that most of the clients who come to see her at her tailoring business consistently commend her for her lively disposition, a characteristic that she says has helped her make financial headway. She initially began her tailoring endeavor, which is based in the town of Lugazi, at the persuasion of a good friend. With 200,000 shillings in weekly profits, Mary is pleased with her business's prospects. 

With this loan, she wants to purchase more clothes-making textile material. 

Mary belongs to Matale Group - Lugazi.

loans.use: To purchase textiles for clothes-making

loans.name: Matale Women's Group 1 - Lugazi

texts.en: M. Robinah belongs to the Matale Women’s group in Lugazi. This mother of eight has for the last 20 years operated a business with the help of her husband and her sister. She sells food items (mostly tomatoes), shoes, and clothes. She began this business with a PEARL micro-loan. Before she started her endeavor, she was a farmer. She now earns 70,000 shillings a week in profits. With this loan, Robinah says she wants to expand her business. This will be in the form of further purchases of more tomatoes as well as cassava and fresh beans, new pairs of shoes, and clothing items to offer for sale.

loans.use: To purchase more food items as well as new pairs of shoes and clothes to offer for resale

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Payment of college tuition

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: The Kiva borrower is a 23-year-old single man from Lebanon living with his parents. He has owned a small car repair shop for almost three years. He has been working in this industry for more than six years. He is engaged to a girl from his town and they are planning to get married soon, which is why he works to hard to earn income and finalize all the related preparations. Today, he is requesting a loan of $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase more spare car parts to expand his business. He expects the coming year to be successful and to further increase his business productivity.

loans.use: To purchase more spare car parts

loans.name: Gemma

To make a living, Gemma operates a motorcycle transport business. The main source of income for the business comes from operating tricycle transport services. Gemma has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. loans.name: Yokana

texts.en:
The hard-working O. Yokana has operated a growing spare-parts business in the Butunduzi trading centre in Kyenjojo for two years. With a monthly net profit of 180,000 Ugandan shillings, this married father of two children has enjoyed a heightened standard of living through running this lucrative business. He sells spare parts for bicycles and motorcycles.

As a result of his success, he has made enormous progress building his home and paying his family's bills. His first priority after acquiring this loan is to purchase a larger stock of spare parts, with the sole objective of turning his business into a bid supplies store for motorcycle and bicycle parts. This will help him gain more sales revenue to cater to his family's needs.

loans.use: To purchase a larger supply of spare bicycle and motorcycle spare parts for his shop

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie I. is from the village of Brgy. Villaros, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 33 years old and single. To make a living, Melanie owns and operates a business venture in the food sector preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Melanie has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2009, Melanie joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Melanie is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her third from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Elmira

texts.en:
Elmira I. is 43 years old, married and has three children. She was born into a low-income family with many children. She graduated from secondary school, but could not continue her studies because she had to help in the house: she pastured the cattle and milked cows. After finishing school, Elmira had to earn money and started to work as a cook at a local cafeteria. When she was 21, she got married and moved to her husband’s house.
Elmira's parents gave her one milk cow as a dowry, which became the first investment in Elmira’s own business. Over more than 20 years, her efforts were aimed at supporting and expanding her household. Elmira managed to multiply the number of cattle and today she has two milk cows, two calves and thirty sheep. She also cultivates wheat, potatoes and perennial herbs on a plot of land and works hard to get a good harvest of high quality products.
Elmira has applied for a loan of 40,000 KGS to buy one bull calf and one cow. With the revenues from this investment, she plans to broaden her business by purchasing more cattle for fattening.

About Bai-Tushum and Partners
Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase a bull calf and a cow

loans.name: Flenda

texts.en:
Flenda M. is 48 years old, married to Josephat M., a 55-year-old mechanic. They have two children aged 14 and 10. Flenda has been operating a green grocery for 11 years with a monthly profit of Kshs.10, 500 

Flenda has no history with any other MFI, and is applying for her seventh loan of Kshs.20, 000 to buy more types of vegetables which will enable her to better serve her customers. During open-air market day the business does very well. People bring their agricultural products to the market, and Flenda can buy from farmers at a better price and later sell to her customers at a profit.

Flenda plans to use the anticipated profit to plough back into the business, to help it grow. She wants to see her children have a better education and realize their goals in the future.

loans.use: To buy more fruit and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Sema

texts.en: Sema A.  is currently in the business of selling fish, rice, simsim (sesame seeds), and is requesting a loan to increase her stock. Sema is 49 years old and married to a farmer. She has four children, two of whom go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to continue growing her business.

loans.use: increase her stock

loans.name: Laidou Group

texts.fr:
Les Cinq  membres du groupe LAIDOU sont 1 femme mariée, 2 veuves et 2 célibataires, ayant une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans et ont en moyenne  4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles monogames à SANOUBOUGOU I un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali) 
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels, la lingerie, les condiments alimentaires et la vente d’articles divers de boutique (omo, bonbon, savon,  sachet de lait en poudre, cigarettes, biscuits, conserves alimentaires etc...)  avec  FATOUMATA B..
Fatoumata B. compte acheter avec son  prêt  25 cartons d'omo, 15 paquets de bonbons,  5 cartons de savon et divers autres petits articles. 
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché et  effectue sa vente sur place dans sa boutique à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, en détail au  comptant et à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 50.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  pour l’appui de son mari dans les dépenses  et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The five members of the LAIDOU group include one married woman, two widows, and two single women, with an average age of 40 and an average of 4 children.  Most of them live in monogamous families in Sanoubougoui, a neighborhood in the city of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali).

This is their first collaboration with the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso, with the goal of better satisfying their customers.  With Fatoumata B., this group of women sells various goods such as underwear, condiments, detergent, candy, soap, powdered milk packets, cigarettes, biscuits, canned goods, etc.

Fatoumata B. plans to use her loan to buy 25 cartons of detergent, 15 packets of candy, 5 cartons of soap, and various other small items.  She buys her supplies in the large market and sells them on a cash or credit basis in her retail store to a customer base made up of men and women.  She expects to make an average monthly profit of 50,000FCFA, part of which will be used to support her husband in their expenses and part of which will be re-invested in the business.

loans.use: Pour acheter divers articles de boutique

loans.name: Limaniya Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe LIMANIYA  (des femmes mariées et veuves) ont en moyenne 35 ans,  3 enfants et vivent dans des  familles monogames à SANOUBOUGOU I un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur deuxième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Le premier prêt fut correctement remboursé. Ce groupe de femmes fait  en générale la vente de tissus et chaussures avec  AMI B., l’achat vente de condiments alimentaires, le bois de chauffe et de l’encens.
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt  10 colis de chaussures et  20 pagnes wax.
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché auprès des grossistes et vend en détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et e femmes, d’une façon ambulante et à domicile.
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 50.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  pour l’appui de son mari dans les dépenses  et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The ten members of the LIMANIYA group (married women and widows) average 35 years of age and three children; they live in monogamous families in SANOUBOUGOU I, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (Mali's third administrative region). This is their second collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to satisfy their customers' needs. The first loan has been correctly repaid. This group of women generally sells fabrics and shoes (especially B. Ami) and trade in food condiments, burning wood and incense.
Mariam plans on purchasing ten shoe packages and twenty wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth) with this loan.
She gets her supplies from wholesalers at the grand market and sells retail, cash or credit, to a customer base composed of both men and women, either door-to-door or from her home.
She is counting on an average monthly benefit of 50,000 CFA francs, some of which will be used to support her husband for expenses, with the remainder being reinvested in her activity.

texts.en:

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Royal Group

texts.fr:
Les Cinq membres du groupe ROYAL (3  femmes mariées  et  2celibataires) ont une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans et ont en moyenne  2 enfants. Elles vivent  dans des  familles monogames à SANOUBOUGOU I un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers en générale tels la vente de fruits et légumes avec MARIAM T. Traoré,  des  condiments , du bois de chauffe, des vêtements et de l’encens.
MARIAM T. compte acheter avec son  prêt,  2 chargements de charrette en fruits et légumes auprès des paysans producteurs et les vend au marché et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, en détail au comptant et à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 50.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  pour l’appui de son mari dans les dépenses  et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The five members of the Royal group (three married women and two single women) average 30 years of age and have on average two children each. They live in mongamous families in Sanoubougou 1, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (Mali's third administrative region).

They are on their first loan from the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the goal of satisfying customer demand. This group of women sell a variety of things, such as fruit and vegetables (as is the case for Mariam T.), condiments, firewood, clothes and incense.

With her loan Mariam T. is planning on buying two barrow loads of fruit and vegetables from the peasants that produce them, and then sell them at the market and within the family, on a retail basis for cash and on credit, to a customer base made up of men and women. 

She is expecting to make an average monthly profit of 50,000FCFA, of which part will be used to help her husband with the daily expenses and the rest invested in her business.

loans.use: To buy fruit

loans.name: Kotognogotala Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe KOTOGNOGOTALA sont  toutes  des   femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans et ont en moyenne  2 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogames à SANOUBOUGOU I un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur deuxième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, le prêt passé à été bien remboursé. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce  d’articles divers  tels  l’huile alimentaire avec ADIARATOU B., les condiments alimentaires, des poissons , des tissus et des boissons non alcoolisées.
ADIARATOU B. compte acheter avec son  prêt, 10 bidons d’huile. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Sikasso. L’huile est vendue en famille et au marché, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant, en détail et quelques fois à crédit  . 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 40.000FCFA dont la totalité sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The ten members of the KOTOGNOGOTALA group are married women who average 30 years of age and two children each. They live for the most part in monogamous families in Sanoubougou I, a district of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali).

This is their second time collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to meet the needs of their customers. The first loan was fully repaid. 

They sell sundry items such as condiments, fish, fabrics and non-alcoholic beverages. ADIARATOU B. sells cooking oil.

With the loan, Adiaratou B. plans to buy 10 cans of oil. She gets her stocks at the big market of Sikasso. The oil is then sold within the family, and also at the market, at retail, to a clientele of men and women, for cash and sometimes on credit.

She expects to earn an average monthly profit of 40 000FCFA to be fully re-invested in her activities.

loans.use: To buy oil

loans.name: Kounandi Group

texts.fr:
KOUNANDI est un regroupement de quatre femmes toutes mariées ayant en moyenne 35 ans, 4 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles monogames à SANOUBOUGOU I un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali) 
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers en générale, tels la vente de savon avec Kadia C., du charbon de  bois et des  vêtements pour d’enfants .
 KADIA C. compte acheter avec son  prêt,  10 cartons de savon.
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché et les vend  dans les villages voisins et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes,  au comptant et en détail. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 50.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  pour l’appui de son mari dans les dépenses  et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
Kounadi is a group of four women who are all married, average 35 years of age and have on average four children each. The majority of them live in monogamous families in Sanoubougou 1, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (Mali's third administrative region).

They are collaborating for the first time with the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the goal of satisfying customer demand. This group of women sells a variety of general products, including soaps (as is the case for Kadia C.), firewood and children's clothing. 

With her loan, Kadia C. is planning on buying ten cartons of soap. She gets her supplies at the large market and sells them, for cash and on a retail basis, in neighboring villages and within her family, to a customer base made up of men and women. 

She is expecting to make an average monthly profit of 50,000FCFA, of which part will be used to help her husband with the daily expenses and the rest invested in her business.
