loans.name: Damira's Group

texts.en:
Damira K. is the leader of this group. She is 48 and married. She has three daughters. Her two older daughters are married and live separately with their families and the third daughter is at school. Damira is engaged in cultivating strawberries and her husband works as a taxi-driver. Damira wants to start a cattle breeding activity. She hopes to obtain the loan to purchase cattle. In the future she wants to purchase a house.

Gulaisha S. is the treasurer of the group. She is 50 and married. She has a daughter and two sons. She works as a janitor and her husband works in construction in Kazakhstan. Gulaisha wants to start a cattle breeding activity. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase cattle in order to resell them at a higher price after fattening. 

Nurlan S., 30, is married.  He has two daughters; both of them are preschool age (under seven).  Nurlan makes money by selling clothes on the market. In this way he makes 11700 soms per month. He hopes to obtain the loan because he wants to expand his business and purchase more clothes. 

Omurbek K., 31, is married. He has a newborn son. Omurbek works in construction, he is also engaged in farming. He cultivates strawberries. His wife wants to start selling clothes at the market. Omurbek hopes to obtain the loan because he needs money to purchase clothes for sale. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Lanaya Group

texts.fr:
Les Cinq membres du groupe LANAYA sont toutes des  femmes mariées  avec une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans, et ont en moyenne  3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogames à SANOUBOUGOU I un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur deuxième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, le prêt précédent à été bien remboursé. Ce groupe de femmes fait l’achat vente de produits de beauté avec  AICHA C.,  du savon, des chaussures et de l‘arachide.
AICHA C. compte acheter avec son  prêt  2 cartons de produits de beauté
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché et les vend de façon ambulante en ville .
Les produits  sont vendus aussi en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 50.000 FCFA qui  sera utilisée  dans les dépenses  de la famille.
texts.en:
The five members of the Lanaya group are all married, average 35 years of age and have on average three children each. Most of them live in monogamous families in Sanoubougou 1, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (Mali's third administrative region).

They are on their second loan from the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the goal of satisfying customer demand. The previous loan has been repaid in full. This group of women buy and sell beauty products (this is the case for Aicha C.), soap, shoes and peanuts. 

With her loan Aicha C. is planning on buying two cartons of beauty products. She gets her supplies at the large market and sells them walking around the town. She also sells her products with her family to a customer base made up of men and women, for cash.
 
She is expecting to make an average monthly profit of 50,000FCFA, of which part will be used for daily expenses.

loans.use: To buy beauty products

loans.name: Aminatu

texts.en: Aminatu M. sells boiled yams and serves them with "kontommire" stew (normally called "palava sauce"). She has attained junior high level of education. She is married to a driver and has two children. She will use the loan to purchase more yams and other ingredients for sale. She will use the new income from her business to buy other foods to cook in addition to the yams to sell.

loans.use: purchase more yams and other ingredients for sale

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel A. is from the village of Calamagui. He is 38 years old. Emmanuel is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Emmanuel owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Emmanuel has been engaged in his business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP when he sells his raised pig.

In 2010, Emmanuel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emmanuel is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Emmanuel from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Sanayelen Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe SANAYELEN sont  quatre femmes  toutes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans,  5 enfants et vivant dans des  familles monogames à SANOUBOUGOU I un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur deuxième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce  d’articles divers en générale tels la vente de tubercules avec  ROKIATOU D., les condiments alimentaires, les habits, du charbon de bois etc.
ROKIATOU D. compte acheter avec son  prêt,  3 chargements de charrette en tubercules (ignames, patate douce, pomme de terre, manioc)
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché et  dans les villages voisins. Les tubercules sont  vendus en famille et au marché à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, en détail, au comptant et souvent à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 65.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  pour l’appui de son mari dans les dépenses  et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Sanayelen group are four women who are all married, average 35 years of age and have on average five children each. They live in monogamous families in Sanoubougou 1, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (Mali's third administrative region).

They are on their second loan from the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso. This group of women sell a variety of general products, such as tubers (this is the case for Rokiatou D.), condiments, clothing, firewood etc.

With her loan Rokiatou D. is planning on buying three barrow loads of tubers (yams, sweet potatoes, ordinary potatoes, cassava). She gets her supplies at the large market and in neighboring villages. She sells the tubers within the family and at the market, on a retail basis for cash and often on credit, to a customer base made up of men and women. 

She is expecting to make an average monthly profit of 65,000FCFA, of which part will be used to help her husband with the daily expenses and the rest invested in her business.

loans.use: To purchase tubers

loans.name: Nafisa

texts.en: Nafisa M. has no educational background. She is married and takes care of six dependents. Nafisa sells cassava, plantains, and cooks 'banku' (fermented corn dough) and sells rice as well at Abura. She helps her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. She will use the loan to buy more of her goods for sale. She plans on reinvesting her profit back into her business.

loans.use: buy more of her goods for sale

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe Benkadi sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 37ans, 3 enfants et  vivant dans des familles monogames à Hamdallaye  un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, (3ème région administrative du Mali : Sikasso). 
Elles sont à leur huitième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Les  sept prêts précédents ont tous été bien soldés. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles différents et de poissons  avec AMI K..
AMI K. compte acheter avec son  prêt 15 kg de poissons frais + 1 barre de glace.  Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Sikasso ville.
Elle mène son activité à Sikasso ville (au marché de Hamdallaye et à domicile). Elle effectue sa vente  au comptant, en détail et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 32.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elle  ambitionne s’acheter un lot à usage d’habitation à Sikasso.
texts.en:
The five members of the Benkadi group are essentially married women, who average 37 years of age and have on average three children each. They live in monogamous families in Hamdallaye, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (Mali's third administrative region).

They are on their eighth loan from the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the goal of satisfying customer demand. All the seven previous loans have been repaid in full. This group of women sell a variety of items, including fish (this is the case for Ami K.).

With her loan Ami K. is planning on buying 15kg of fresh fish and a block of ice. She gets her supplies at Sikasso town's large market and she carries out her business in Sikasso town (at the market in Hamdallaye and from home). She sells for cash, on a retail basis and for credit to a customer base made up of men and women. 

She is expecting to make an average monthly profit of 32,500FCFA, of which part will be used for savings and family needs, and the rest invested in her business. Her ambition is to buy a piece of land to live on in Sikasso.

loans.use: To buy fish

loans.name: Fatima's Group

texts.en:
Fatima T. is the leader of this group. She is 46 and married. Her husband works is a taxi-driver.  She has two sons and two daughters. The first son and daughter are working and the others are students.  Fatima makes money by taking orders and sewing Kyrgyz national blankets. In this way she makes 20,000 soms per month.  With money received from the loan she wants to purchase fabrics and materials for sewing. 

Zuurakan M. is the treasurer of the group. She is 45 and married. He husband is a taxi-driver. She has a daughter and a son; both of them are employed. Zuurakan makes money by sewing Kyrgyz national blankets.  She started three years ago with the initial investment of 5000 soms and now she earns 15,000 soms per month.  With money received from the loan she wants to purchase a sewing machine. 

Gapar M., 48, is married. He has four daughters.  Gapar works as a taxi-driver and his wife is a teacher at school.  Gapar also breeds cattle to earn money. He resells the cattle after fattening at a higher price. He hopes to obtain the loan because he needs money to purchase hay for his cattle.

Ziyada A., 33, is married. She has two daughters and a son. Ziyada is engaged in cattle breeding and her husband works as a taxi-driver. With money received from the loan, Ziyada wants to purchase hay for her cattle.
 
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics and materials

loans.name: Balyewunya Mixed Group-Mukono

texts.en:
Succeeding in life is something that comes with a lot of hard work and after taking stock of one's surroundings. With a tenacious work ethic in operating her 8-year-old pub business, 46-year-old Sarah N. has made sure that all bets are off in her march towards better prospects in her business and her life. Previously, Sarah operated a bread-making enterprise. Typically, she earns 60,000 shillings per week.

Sarah is now requesting a loan as part of the group loan to purchase more crates of high-flavor beverages for her pub. She belongs to Balyewunya Mixed group-Mukono.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional beverages

loans.name: Bakusekamajja Development Group-Mukono

texts.en:
Godfrey K. is a resolute, hard-working, and strong-willed 48-year-old businessman who belongs to Bakusekamajja group-Mukono. For 6 years, he has operated a fish-selling business. He explains that it has been a worthwhile endeavor in terms of providing wealth and support for his family and extricating himself out of a life of poverty. In a week this married father of 4 typically earns 60,000 shillings.

He is now requesting a loan to purchase more fish for resale purposes.

loans.use: To expand and improve his business by purchasing additional fish

loans.name: Perisca

texts.en:
Perisca E. is a 20-year-old, married woman. Her husband is a farmer. They have 4 children, and all of their children attend school.

At present, Perisca is in the business of selling oil, sugar, simsim, and groundnuts. She is seeking a loan to increase her inventory relating to simsim and groundnuts for resale purposes. With the additional profits generated as a result of this loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by increasing her stock of products

loans.name: Kotognogonta Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe Kotognogontala sont essentiellement des  femmes mariées  avec une moyenne d’âge de 43 ans  et 3 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des familles monogames à Hamdallaye  un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, (3ème région administrative du Mali : Sikasso). 
Elles sont à leur cinquième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso, après avoir correctement remboursés les quatre prêts précédents. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce en générale et des prestations de service telle que la teinture avec KADIA D..
KADIA D. compte acheter avec son  prêt, 4 paquets de colorants différents +10kg de soude caustique + deux chargements de charrette en bois de chauffe. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Sikasso ville et ses villages avoisinants.
Elle méne son activité à domicile au comptant et à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elle compte avoir plus de capitaux pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle et  pouvoir aménager un coin pour le besoin.
texts.en:
The four members of the group Kotognogontala are essentially married women averaging 43 years of age and three children.  The women live for the most part in monogamous families in Hamdallaye, a district in Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali:  Sikasso).  They are on their fifth collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso after having properly repaid the four previous loans.  This group of women works in general commerce and provides services, such as the dying of cloth (in the case of Ms. KADIA D.).

KADIA D. plans to use her loan to buy 4 packets of different dyes, 10 kg of caustic soda, and two cart loads of firewood.  She gets her supplies at the big market of Sikasso City and from neighboring villages of hers.  She operates her business out of her home.  Accepting cash, she sells to a customer base composed of men and women.  

She envisions making an average monthly profit of 35,500 francs CFA.  Part of the profits will be put into savings and used for family needs.  The other part will be invested in business.  She plans on obtaining more capital in order to satisfy her customers better and to be able to fix up the needed area.

loans.use: Buying dyes and the supplies to dye cloth

loans.name: Antoinette

texts.fr:
Femme commerçante de 59ans marié et mère de 2 enfants agée de 39ans à 18ans dont 1 enfant est scolarisé.Elle se lance dans le commerce d'habillement en 1975 avec un capital de 60000 frs cfa. Ses revenus journaliers varient de 5000 à 30000frs.
Avec ce prêt elle va renforcer son commerce en achetant des robes fillette,des sous-vêtement,des sandales enfants filles comme hommes.
Elle a pour strategie de reserver un bon acceuil à ses clients, présenter un bon éttallage et faire la variation des produit ainsi que des couleurs sur son étallages.
Elle aimerait être grossiste et bien situé ses enfants surtout celui de 18ans.
Dans le quartier elle est la maman de tous les enfants.
texts.en:
This businesswoman is a 59-year-old, married mother of two children, ages 39 and18, one of whom has attended school. She started selling clothing in 1975 with a capital of 60,000FCFA. Her daily income varies from 5,000 to 30,000 francs.

With this loan, she plans to strengthen her business by buying dresses for girls, underwear, and children’s sandals.

Her strategy includes a warm greeting to her customers, a nice display of her merchandise, and variety in the types and colors of products she offers.

She would like to become a wholesaler and provide a good future for her children, especially the 18-year-old. In the neighborhood, she is a mother to all children.

loans.use: To buy clothes, underwear, and sandals

loans.name: Benkadi (Entente) Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi sont toutes mariées, elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans, 7 enfants et vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Chien Kamakan ex-arrondissement de Yangasso, préfecture de SAN  (région de SEGOU République du Mali). 
Elles se sont  connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Elles exercent presque la même activité d’achat et de vente  des condiments et de diverses marchandises. Elles sont très sollicitées dans ces différentes activités. 
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de leurs clientèles qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe a décidé d’intégrer ’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son premier  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). 
DJENEBOU T., la présidente du groupe compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une grande quantité de  condiments alimentaires à un prix abordable à Bla. Les condiments sont vendus en détail et au comptant  à la foire hebdomadaire du village et dans les autres foires environnantes du village. 
Elle espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen  de 10.000 FCFA  qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités. 
Elle ambitionne d’agrandir son commerce avec l’ouverture d’un magasin de vente de condiments.
texts.en:
The women who form the Benkadi group are all married, averaging 33 years of age and 7 children. They live in traditional extended families in the village of Chien-Kamakan, ex-district of Yangasso, San Prefecture (Segou Region of Mali). They know each other as neighbors and relatives. They all do similar work, buying and reselling condiments and various goods. Their businesses are very popular with customers.

In order to meet the ever growing customer demand, the group members decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yriwaso and are now on the first solidarity loan (group loan). Djenebou T., the group’s leader, plans to use her loan to purchase a large quantity of food condiments at reasonable prices. The condiments are retailed for cash at the weekly market at their village and at other nearby markets. Djenebou plans to achieve an average monthly income of 10,000 West African Francs, which will be used to pay off the interest on her loan and provide for family needs, with the rest reinvested in her business. Her goal is to enlarge her business and open a condiment store.

loans.use: Purchasing condiments

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary K. is a single, 29-year-old woman. She has one child, who currently attends school.

To earn a living, Mary operates a small business where she sells tomatoes and fish. She is requesting a loan to stock more fish to sell. With the extra profits generated as a result of this loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business by increasing her fish inventory

loans.name: Nafisatu

texts.en: Nafisatu A. is married and has three children. She has been through junior high school. She sells porridge in Abura. She helps her husband provide for the basic needs of the family. She will use this loan to buy more ingredients to prepare her porridge for sale. She hopes to use the new profit from her business to buy land.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients to prepare her porridge for sale

loans.name: Jypargul's Group

texts.en:
Jypargul S. is the leader of this group. She is a 43-year-old, married woman. She and her husband have a son and a daughter. She works in a bakery, while her husband is a teacher. Two years ago, with an initial investment of 15,000 KGS, Jypargul and her husband started to breed cattle. By breeding and ultimately selling cattle, they earn 8,000 KGS per month. She is seeking a loan to purchase additional cattle for breeding purposes. In the future, she wants to provide her children with a great education.

Gulmira C. is the treasurer of the group. She is a 39-year-old, married woman. She and her husband have a daughter and a son, both of whom are in school. Gulmira and her husband work in a bakery. Two years ago, with an initial investment of 15,000 KGS, they began breeding livestock. She is requesting a loan to purchase additional livestock.

Halypa K. is a 49-year-old, married woman. She and her husband have a daughter and a son, both of whom are employed. Halypa sells apples in the market. She is asking for a loan to purchase apples in bulk in order to re-sell them at a higher price on the market. In the near future she would like to start repairing her house.

Almambet T. is a 45-year-old, married man. He and his wife have a son and two daughters. Almambet works in construction and his wife is a housekeeper. Two years ago, with an initial investment of 5,000 KGS, Almambet started breeding cattle. He is now hoping to secure this loan to purchase cattle for breeding.

This loan is being sought through Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious, and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is firmly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers and as society), planet (being environmentally-friendly), and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days per year. To learn more about MBF and to view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join the group's lending team at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional cattle

loans.name: Edith  Gertrude

texts.fr:
Femme de 30ans mariée et mère de 5 enfants dont l'âge varie de 21ans à 2ans et 6 mois dont 4 sont scolariser et ayant 2 enfants à charge.ayant une grande charge avec elle,elle debute avec son commerce en 1991 avec un capital de 500f. ses recettes par jour sont de 6000 à 70000frs par jours.

Avec ce prêt elle aimerait acheter un filet des oignon, des caisses de tomate, des poivrons, des aubergines,le percil, de la ciboule, carotte, choux.

Malgre les difficultés de mevente dûe à cause de la production elle à poue strategie de bien gerer ses avoir épargner pour renforcer son capital, faire la variation des produits sur son etallage et reserver un bon acceuil à ses clients.

ella a pour ambition d'avoir une boutique afin d'être grossiste, de construire une maison ainsi que bien situer ses enfants grâce aux études à l'étranger.
texts.en: Mrs. B. is a 30 year old woman, married and the mother of five children, who vary in age between 2 years, 6 months and 21 years old, 4 of whom are educated and two of whom are still in her care.  Having many responsibilities, she began her business in 1991 with 500f in start-up funds.  Her daily receipts are between 6000 and 70,000 frs.  With this loan, she would like to buy a bag of onions, some cases of tomatoes, some peppers, eggplants, parsley, spring onions, carrots, cabbage, etc.  Despite the difficulties brought on by a drop in sales due to production, her strategy is to manage her savings so that she may support her means, offer a variety of products at her stall, and maintain a welcoming area for her customers.  Her goal is to have a boutique in which to sell at wholesale, to build a house, as well as to set her children up for success through studies abroad.

loans.use: To purchase onions tomatoes and peppers

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Djekafo  est un regroupement de 10 femmes  qui se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage. Elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 36 ans, sont mariées et mères de 8 enfants. Elles mènent différentes activités : vente de riz, de condiments. Elles vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles à Chien Kamakan de Yangasso, préfecture de SAN (Région de Ségou, République du Mali). Les femmes du groupe sont très sollicitées dans leurs activités. 
Dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin croissant de leur clientèle, le groupe a décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso cette année et est à son premier prêt. 
KARIYA S. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter pour acheter, 900 kg de riz au marché de Bla  en vu de le revendre à la foire hebdomadaire. Elle espère sur un bénéfice mensuel  de 12500 FCFA qui lui  permettra de rembourser le prêt et de réinvestir dans son activité.
Les autres membres comptent sur un bénéfice de 11.000 FCFA par mois  somme qui leur permettra de rembourser le prêt et de subvenir aux besoins familiales
texts.en:
Djekafo is a group of 10 women who know one another through parental and neighborly ties.  They are, on average, 36 years old, married and the mothers of 8 children.  They run different businesses: the sale of rice, condiments.  They live in large traditional families in Chien Kamakan de Yangasso, the SAN prefecture (in the Ségou region of the Republic of Mali).  The women of the group are very sought-after in their business.  With the goal of satisfying the growing needs of their customer base, the group has decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit program this year and are on their first loan.  

Kariya S. expects to use her first loan to buy 900 kg of rice at the Bla market, with the hope of reselling it at the weekly fair.  She hopes to makes a monthly profit of 12,500 FCFA which will allow her to repay the loan and to reinvest in her busienss.  The other members expect to make a profit of 11,000 FCFA per month, which will allow them to repay the loan and to support their families' needs.

loans.use: To purchase rice

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en: Lilia P. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes, onions, etc. and is requesting a loan to start a fish farming business.  A 45-year-old widow, Lilia has five children, four of whom go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: To start a fish farming business

loans.name: Chinikul

texts.en:
Chinikul K., a 57-year-old pensioner, lives in At-Bashy village in the mountainous area of Kyrgyzstan. She is married and has six grown children, five of whom live on their own, while the youngest son, in accordance with Kyrgyz national tradition, lives with her and helps with the household. Chinikul and her husband Beyshenaly have been married for over 40 years and support each other.

Chinikul has been engaged in cattle breeding most of her life, and her experience and hardworking personality have enabled her to maintain a successful farm and enlarge her number of cattle. Today she has eight horses and eight cows and sheep which were obtained with her first loan, which was repaid without any delays. She plans to use this loan of 100,000 KGS to broaden her number of cattle for fattening and reselling. In the future, Chinikul plans to renovate her house and hold her son’s wedding.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Arshavir

texts.en:
Arshavir H. was born in 1949 in Sevakar village, Kapan area. He is married and has two children, who are already married. 
Arshavir and his wife are farmers – they keep cows, calves, sheep and beehives. Arshavir’s working day starts at 6 a.m. and lasts till late evening, but he has never complained about it and deals with the hard work with pleasure. This kind of zealous work allows him to make good profit and keeps his family. Arshavir asks for a 750.000 Armenian dram loan to buy some sheep for his farm.

loans.use: To buy some sheep for his farm

loans.name: Davlatbek

texts.ru: Эгамбердиев Давлатбек проживает в районе Дж. Руми. Возраст, 60 лет. Женат, имеет 11 детей. Дети занимаются растениеводством. Сам Давлатбек имеет высшее образование. Он закончил академию, то есть высшую школу Милиции. По профессии проработал более 20 лет. Сейчас клиент занимается животноводством. Он разводит скот у себя дома. В основном Давлатбек разводит скот в дальнейшем для перепродажи. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 10 лет. Кредит берет для закупа скота, чтобы увеличить их количество.
texts.en: Davlatbek E. lives in the J. Rumy district.  He is 60 years old, married and has 11 children.  His children are involved in agriculture.  Davlatbek has a higher education.  He graduated from an academy, i.e. top police school.  He spent 20 years working in that field.  Now the client is involved in animal husbandry.  He breeds livestock at home.  Davlatbek primarily breeds livestock for future resale.  He has been in this business for 10 years.  He is requesting this loan for the purchase of livestock, in order to increase its quantity.

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Edina

texts.en: Edina Y. is currently in the business of selling groundnuts (peanuts), simsim (sesame seed) and cowpeas and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of cowpeas to sell. Edina is 27 years old and widowed with five children. Only two of her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: To stock more bags of cowpeas to sell

loans.name: Djiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les dix femmes du groupe Djiguisseme ont une moyenne d’âge de 29 ans, sont mariées et mères d’au moins 4  enfants. Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage et  mènent différentes activités : vente de tissus et de bijoux. Elles vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles à Chien Kamakan   dans l’ex-arrondissement de Yangasso  préfecture  de SAN (Région de Ségou, République du Mali). 
Les femmes du groupe sont très sollicitées dans leurs activités. 
Dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin croissant de leur clientèle, le groupe a décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso cette année. Il est à son premier prêt. 
NANA T., compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter,  3 pièces de pagnes wax et une douzaine de boucles d’oreille au marché de Bla en vu de  les revendre à la foire hebdomadaire du village et environs. 
Elle espère sur un bénéfice mensuel  de 17.500 FCFA somme qui lui  permettra de rembourser le prêt et de réinvestir dans son activité.
Les autres membres comptent sur un bénéfice de 7000 FCFA par mois  somme qui leur permettra de rembourser le prêt et de subvenir aux besoins familiaux.
texts.en:
The ten women of the Djiguisseme group are, on average, 29 years old, married and the mothers of at least 4 children.  They know one another through parental and neighborly ties and run different businesses: the sale of cloth and jewelry.  They live in large traditional families in the outer-neighborhood of the Yangasso prefecture of SAN (in the Ségou region of the Republic of Mali).  The women of the group are very sought-after in their business.  With the goal of satisfying the growing needs of their customer base, the group has decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit program this year.  They are on their first loan.

Nane T. expects to use her first loan to buy three pieces of wax loincloths and a dozen pairs of earrings at the Bla market, with the goal of reselling them at the weekly fair of her village and the surrounding areas.  She hopes to make a monthly profit of 17,500 FCFA which will allow her to pay back her loan and to reinvest in her business.  The other members of the group expect a profit of 7000 FCFA per month which will permit them to repay the loan and to support their families' needs.

loans.use: To buy various items

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet A. has been selling variety of items as a wholesale trader in Mahanga village, in Vihiga, for 11 years. He has had a profit margin of KES13,500. She is married to Evans Ababu who is a primary school teacher, and they have two children age nine years, and six years.

Janet is applying for her second loan of KES 40,000 with KADET LTD. after she paid back her previous loan successfully. She intends to buy more stock of various items like plastic basins, jugs, and buckets worth KES 40,000 in bulk. She will sell the items to traders at wholesale price. She will use the anticipated profit invest back into the business to grow it and to be in a position of financial stability.

She desires to have a business with a capital base of one million KES.

loans.use: To buy more stock of various items like plastic basins,jugs, buckets worth KES 40,000.

loans.name: Margrete

texts.en: Magrete K. is currently in the business of selling beans, simsim and other food items and is requesting a loan to stock more foods like cassava, potatoes etc. to sell. Magrete is 36 years old. She is married and her husband is a businessman. She has 4 children and 2 of her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: To stock more food stall like cassava, potatoes etc. to sell.

loans.name: Kunduzhan's Group

texts.en:
Kunduzhan A. is the leader of the group. She is 46 and married. She has two sons. Her first son is handicapped and the second is a teacher of physical training at school. Kunduzhan works in the gas station and her husband works in construction in Kazakhstan. Two years ago, with the initial investment of 2000 soms, Kunduzhan started to breed livestock. With money received from this loan, she wants to purchase farm animals for breeding. In the future she wants to see her sons married.
 
Bermet A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 44 and a widow. She has a daughter who is 25, married, and lives separately with her husband.  Bermet works in the shop, she applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase convenience goods in order to increase the turnover of her business. 

Aizada S., 25, is married. She has a two year old son. Her husband works as a private driver. She applied for the loan because she wants to improve her living conditions and purchase household appliances. 

Arstanbek T. is 25 years old. He works as a security guard. Two years ago with the initial investment of 2000 soms he started to breed livestock. With money received from the loan he wants to purchase livestock for breeding. In the future he plans to get married.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase farm animals for breeding.

loans.name: Yeredon Group

texts.fr:
YEREDON est un groupe de l’Association Soro Yiriwaton du village de Chien Kamakan. Il regroupe 10 femmes dont la présidente est FATOUMATA D.. Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage. Elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans, sont. mariées et mères d’au moins 6  enfants.  Elles mènent différentes activités  telles la  vente de riz, de condiments alimentaires etc. Elles vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles à Chien Kamakan dans l’ex-arrondissement de Yangasso, préfecture de SAN (Région de Ségou, République du Mali). Elles ont commencé leurs activités à bas âge auprès de leurs parents et sont très appréciées et  sollicitées dans leurs activités. 
Dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin croissant de leur clientèle, le groupe a décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier prêt. 
FATOUMATA D. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter,  300 kg de riz au marché de Bla  en vu de le revendre à  la foire hebdomadaire du village en détail et au comptant aux consommateurs. 
Elle espère sur un bénéfice mensuel de 10.000FCFA somme qui lui  permettra de rembourser le prêt et de réinvestir dans son activité.
NB : ALIMA  D. est absente de la photo pour raison de maladie.
texts.en:
Yeredon is a group in the Soro Yiriwaton Association of the village of Chien Kamakan.  There are ten women in the group, whose president is Fatoumata D..  These women know one another through parental and neighborly ties.  They are, on average, 40 years old, married and the mothers of at least 6 children.  They run different businesses such as the sale of rice, condiments, etc.  They live in large traditional families in Chien Kamakan in the ex-neighborhood of Yangasso, in the SAN prefecture (in the Ségou region of the Republic of Mali).  They started their business at a young age along side of their parents, and are very appreciated and sought-after in their businesses.  With the goal of meeting the growing needs of their customer base, the group has decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit program, with whom they are on their first loan.  

Fatoumata D. expects to use her loan to buy 300 kg of rice at the Bla market in order to resell it at retail and for cash at the weekly village fair to consumers.  She hopes to make a monthly profit of 10,000 FCFA which will allow her to repay her loan and to reinvest in her business.

NB: Alima D. is absent from the photo due to illness.

loans.use: To purchase rice

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Benkadi est un regroupement de 5 femmes qui se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage. Elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 46 ans, sont toutes mariées, mères 9 enfants et vivent dans le village de  Guelekoro dans des grandes familles traditionnelles, dans la préfecture de SAN (Région de Ségou, République du Mali). 
Elles font le petit commerce depuis plusieurs années et excellent dans l’achat vente du poisson sous plusieurs formes à l’image de la présidente du groupe DIKORE G.. 
Dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin croissant de leur clientèle, le groupe  a décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso cette année  et est à son premier prêt. 
DIKORE G. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 10 paniers de poisons dont 8 frais et 2 fumées qu’elle revendra sur place aux revendeurs venant des grandes villes, surtout au comptant. 
Elle espère  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel  de 15.000 FCFA qui lui  permettra de rembourser le prêt et de réinvestir dans son  activité.
texts.en:
Benkadi is a group of 5 women who know one another through marital and neighborly ties.  They are, on average, 46 years old, all married, the mothers of 9 children and live in the village of Guelekoro in large traditional families, in the SAN prefecture (in the Ségou region of the Republic of Mali).
They have run small businesses for several years and they excel in the sale of fish, prepared in many ways, following the image of the group's president, Dikore G..  With the hope of meeting the growing needs of their customers, the group has decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit program this year and on their first loan.  

Dikore G. expects to use her loan to buy 10 baskets of fish, 8 of which will be fresh and 2 smokes, that she will resell there to resellers coming from large cities, especially for cash.  She expects to make a monthly profit of 15,000 FCFA which will permit her to repay her loan and reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To buy fresh and smoked fish

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To stock more clothes and shoes to sell.

loans.name: Donmurod

texts.ru: Шерматов Донмурод проживает в районе Дж. Руми. Возраст, 73 года. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Образование высшее, инженер. По профессии проработал 9 лет. Сейчас он предоставляет услугу, такси. Занимается перевозкой людей. В этой области более 5 лет. Кредит берет для приобретения шин. Клиент готовит свою машину на зиму.
texts.en: Donmurod S. lives in the J. Rumy district.  He is 73 years old, married and has 5 children.  He has a higher education, as an engineer.  He worked in his field for 9 years.  Currently, Donmurod provides taxi service.  He is involved in passenger transportation.  He has been in this business for over 5 years.  He is requesting this loan for the purchase of tires.  Client is preparing his car for the winter.

loans.use: Purchase of tires

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
This is Rosalina D., 47, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Teodulo D., a vendor and her business partner. She is mother to their children: one is already working while three are still in school. By the grace of God, Rosalina has managed to support her older children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to send her youngest to college. A dream for most poor Filipino parents like Rosalina as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Rosalina sells snacks from a little movable cart. In the Philippines, you haven’t walked ten steps before you encounter a food stall, a store or a little cart selling snacks. It is known here, and all over the world: Filipinos love to eat. Rosalina sells fishballs, much like Singaporean fish cakes, and fish tofu but of denser texture and circular in shape. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 21, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like fishballs, cooking oil, LPG for fuel, condiments and seasonings. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Rosalina dreams to be able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of products like fishballs, cooking oil, LPG for fuel, condiments and seasonings.

loans.name: Phillip

texts.en: Phillip O. is 28 years old and married to Pamella Auma who is a housewife. They have three children: Delan - four years old, Ronald - two years old and Vivian, who is also two years old. Phillip is a tailor who has been in his business for the past four years. He is applying for his first loan from KADET. He was introduced by a friend who is a KADET client. He hopes to use the money to buy five rolls of velvet material for making cushions for sofa sets. His hope is to educate his children well and open up a business for his wife. He also hopes to see his business grow and buy a piece of land to build a house for his family.

loans.use: To buy five rolls of velvet cloth for cushions

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase different kinds of thread and cloth

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Buying Kamanyora cloth for tailoring into different clothing

loans.name: Khoeun

texts.en: Khoeun P. is a 25-year-old farmer who lives in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She is married to Orl, age 30, who shares responsibility for the family by driving a car taxi. Her husband appears in the photo. He runs his business very well, because he has good communication skills which he uses with his customers. Unfortunately, the car is often broken down, and they spend a lot of money on repairs. She hopes to help her husband get a second-hand car, but she does not have enough money to make that possible. So, Khoeun P. requests a loan to purchase a used car for her husband to begin a service business.

loans.use: To purchase a used car for her husband to begin a service business

loans.name: Rosaline

texts.en:
This is Rosaline C., 35. She is a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Arnel C., a driver, and is the mother of a college-aged young adult. By the grace of God, Rosaline has managed to support her child's schooling up to college level - a dream for most Filipino parents like Rosaline as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children. At this time, she is working hard to continue providing her child and her family enough to finance their everyday expenses. 

Rosaline operates an accessory business. What she basically does is buy general merchandise from wholesalers, then sells it piecemeal with a little profit. Products can range from furniture to household appliances, electronic devices, clothing and other products of the like. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options they are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 350 Philippines pesos (Php) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php21,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Rosaline dreams to be able to give her child a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Patrick Ngarama

texts.en:
Patrick has been selling clothes in Naivasha town for the last four years.  He is 30 years old and married to Nancy Wanjiru. They have one child.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his third loan. He paid his previous loans well and in good time. He will use the loan amount to grow his business by moving to a larger place and buying more clothes to sell.

loans.use: To move to a bigger place and buy more clothes

loans.name: Shairgul's Group

texts.en: Shairgul S. is the leader of the group. She is 55 and divorced. She has a 14-year-old daughter who is in school. Five years ago, with the initial investment of 3,000 soms, Shairgul started to breed cattle. She resells cattle at a higher price after fattening them. In this way, she makes 12,000 soms per month. She hopes to obtain the loan because she needs the money to purchase two bulls for breeding. Nazgul K. is the treasurer of the group. She is 34 and married. She has two daughters and a son. The daughters are in school and the son is not yet. In order to make money, Nazgul sells ropes and lassos at the market and her husband works in construction. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase more ropes and lassos in order to increase the turnover of her business. In the future, she wants to open her own store. Anvar I., 37, is married. He has a newborn son. Anvar sells fruits and vegetables at the market. In this way, he makes 15,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, he wants to purchase fruits in order to increase the turnover of his business. With part of the loan, he will purchase cattle for breeding. Mirlan A. is 25 years old. He is a private driver. He hopes to obtain the loan because he needs money to purchase auto parts and repair his vehicle. In the future, he wants to get married and start his own business. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase bulls

loans.name: Souho

texts.fr:
Jeune femme de 29ans, celibataire et mère d'un enfant scolarisé agée de 2ans. elle debute son commerce comme ambulante des mèches au marche en 2006 et grâce à ses épargnes et vend sur une table au marché depuis 2007 avec un capital de 100000Frs. ses recettes journaliers sont de 10000 à 50000frs.

Avec ce prêt elle va acheter des varietés de tissage tel que (tissage naturel noble,olive,x-pression, tissage syntétique),des mèches tel que pony, olive, anglaise, afro ainsi que des postiges.

Elle fait preuve d'une bonne gestion et reserve un bon acceuil à ses clients. elle aimerait effectuer des voyages en afrique de l'ouest afin d'importer la marchandise. Elle aimerait aussi renforcer les conditions de vie de son fils en l'offrant une bonne scolarisation et education.

elle est encourager dans son entourage pour les efforts qu'elle fournit et sa motivation dans son commerce.
texts.en:
This woman is 29 year old, single and the mother of a two-year old child who is in nursery school. She started her business as a street vendor of hair extension back in 2006; thanks to her savings since 2007 she started selling at a market stand in 2007, with a starting capital of 1000,000 West African Francs. Her daily sales average from 10,000 to 50,000 West African francs. 

With this loan she will purchase different types of hair locks (“noble natural”, olive, X-pression brand, synthetic) and hair extensions such as pony, olive, English style, Afro as well as hairpieces. She manages her business well and provides a good service for her customers. She would like to be able to travel to West Africa to import merchandise. She would also like to improve life conditions of her son and to provide a good education for him. Her friends and relatives encourage her in the efforts to grow her business and help boost her confidence.

loans.use: Purchasing different types of hair extensions

loans.name: Bunyod

texts.en:
H. Bunyod is a 29 year old businessman. He is married and, together with his wife, they have 3 kids. Bunyod is a farmer, like his wife. They started their work 5 years ago. The beginning was very difficult, because they needed to invest a lot of working capital. With much effort and the help of his wife he was able to move forward and today has a large plot of land. His vegetables are very good quality which he says is due to the constant irrigation they receive since the business has a complete underground irrigation system. They sell their products in the fruit and vegetable market of the city. Bunyod requests the loan for the purchase of fertilizer and seeds. This will allow him to better provide for his family.  

 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Towards purchasing the seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Peter Waithaka

texts.en:
Peter has been in transport business since 2007. He operates his motorbike around Naivasha town. He is 35 years old, married to Serah Wambui and they have two children.  

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his second loan. He paid his 1st loan of KES 20,000 well and in good time. He plans to use this cash to buy a new motorbike.

In future, Peter hopes to own a taxi which he will still operate in Naivasha town.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more sports materials.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter has been selling clothes and shoes in Naivasha town for the last six years. He is 32 years old, married to Magdalene Wanjiru and they have two children who are going to school.

Peter was introduced to KADET  LTD by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to add stock of trousers and shirts to sell in his shop. In the future, Peter plans to be selling clothes for all people as currently he has specialized only with men clothing.

loans.use: To buy more trousers and shirts to sell.

loans.name: Sherzod

texts.en:
H. Sherzod is married and the father of 3 children. For 8 years he has been engaged in a farming business. The love to his children is the motor that keeps him working hard for their future. He works fast, together with the help of his wife, to achieve quality products. The high prices of fertilizer have caused his production to slow down. He wishes to do better, to have more production and to increase the number of hectares bearing crops. To do it, Sherzod needs capital, which he requests through a loan, and he hopes that you can help him. This way, he can look forward to a profitable production to increase his income and to pay for his children’s education.  
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. loans.use: Towards purchasing seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce O., 53, is a widow who has seven children: Charles (25), Maureen (20), Rose (18), Hezron (16),  Rodgers (14), Kennedy (12), and Dennis (10). They live in Kisumu city.

Joyce has been selling fabric for the past 10 years. She normally sells to the local tailors. She is applying for her second loan from KADET LTD after successfully repaying the first one. She intends to use the money to buy more fabric to add to her stock so she can serve her clients well.

Joyce hopes to see her business expand so she can pay school fees and college fees for her children who depend on her.

loans.use: To buy more fabric

loans.name: Rustam

texts.ru: Ашуров Рустам житель города Турсунзаде. Возраст, 51 год. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Образование высшее, фермер. По профессии работает уже 20 лет. Кроме того занимается животноводством. Он разводит скот у себя дома. В этом ему помогает жена. Кредит берет для закупа бычка и дойной коровы.
texts.en: Rustam A. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda.  He is 51 years old, married and has 4 children.  He has a higher education, as a farmer.  He has been working in his field for 20 years.  Besides that, he is involved in animal husbandry.  Rustam breeds livestock at home.  His wife helps him with this business.  He is requesting this loan in order to purchase a bull and a dairy cow.

loans.use: Purchase of a bull and a dairy cow

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en:
This is 45 year-old Mahmoud. He is married, and has five children aged 18, 15, 6, 4, and 2. 

In 1990, Mahmoud established his luggage business. He began his business to generate income and to take care his family. Working seven days a week and 11 hours a day, he earns about 1,920,000 SLL a month. He would like a loan of 4,500,000 SLL to buy more luggage. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately 384,000 SLL. In the future, Mahmoud plans to further develop his business as well as build a house for himself. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy luggage

loans.name: Mary Otieno

texts.en:
Mary Atieno, 31,  is married and has five children. Her husband, Joshua Otieno, works as a driver to help support the family and pay school fees and rent.

Mary is a fish monger and has been in this business for the past seven years. Her business is strategically placed in the market and she has a huge clientele, including many of the hotels around. She is applying for her first loan. She intends to use the money to buy more fish and add to her stock. Mary's profits will be used to enlarge her business base so as to satisfy all her customers. Her monthly income is 10,000 KES.

Mary's hope is to have a stable business and support her family effectively.

loans.use: Buy more fish

loans.name: Nosir

texts.en:
Nosir H., 27, is married and has two children. He lives in Shahristan and works in the agricultural industry. Five years ago he decided to cultivate the land he owned. He did so to generate more income so he could support his family. Nosir grows wheat, corn, and vegetables, which he carefully tends so that he can produce a full, healthy harvest. He will use the loan money to buy seed and fertilizer that will enable him to improve his production yield. Nosir enjoys doing this job, and that's why he will continue to use loans so he can improve his farm and become a better farmer. 
  
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. Tajikistan has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Khusravjon

texts.en:
Since he was a boy, Khusravjon has loved animals. He has learned to raise them well so that he can market them. Khusravjon is not married and lives with his large family. As the oldest brother, he has to work hard to support his family. He needs to invest in his livestock and sheep breeding business and, consequently, he's asked IMON International for a loan that will allow him to purchase young cattle and the feed for them. Khusravjon is sincerely grateful for your support.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Jumagul

texts.en:
Jumagul has a responsibility that makes her work hard for improvement. She is married and has three kids. To help her husband with family expenses she started a farming business. Jumagul is a woman of humble heart and position who works very hard every day in her fields to produce for her family’s sustenance by planting and tending her crops. Despite the difficulties that Jumagul and her husband have suffered, they persevere; motivated by their desire for a better life. That is why Jumagul is asking for a loan to buy apples wholesale and sell them later, when the prices for them will increase. She wants to expand her business, a success that will bring a better quality of life for her family.

loans.use: Towards purchasing apples wholesale.

loans.name: Melsie

texts.en:
This is 37 year-old Melsie. She is married, and has 1 child, aged 15. In 2008, Melsie established her provisions, drinks and food business.  She began her business in an effort to become independent. Working 6 days a week and 14 hours a day, Melsie earns about SLL 1,356,800 every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 4,500,000.  

Melsie has already received and successfully repaid 1 loan, and now requires a new loan in order to buy additional oil, tomatoes, sweet milk and sugar.  She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately SLL 271,360. In the future, Melsie plans to build a house and educate her child up to university level. Melsie also hopes to eventually become a supplier of provisional goods.  She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: The loan will be used to buy provisions.

loans.name: Abduvosid

texts.en:
For the past 6 years, T. Abduvosid has put much effort into his agricultural activities in the district of Shahristan in Northern Tajikistan. Despite the difficult economic situation that he has gone through, he has managed to support his family and provide his two children with everything they need. To develop his business, Abduvosid has made use of loans provided by IMON International, which he has used toward technical assistance for his crops. Once again, Gulomjon seeks loan support from IMON International to invest in his crops, later raise his harvest, and survive along with his family. With your help, Abduvosid will be able to get ahead.    

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. loans.use: Towards purchasing the seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more dozens of lappas ( a traditional dress for women)

loans.name: Mohamed  A.

texts.en:
This is 31 year-old Mohamed. He is married, and has 2 children, aged 6 and 4.  He has an additional dependent who lives with him, to help take care of his family.  In 1998, Mohamed established his building materials business. He began this business to better take care of his family and to be more self-reliant. 

Working 7 days a week and 12 hours a day, Mohamed earns about SLL 1,713,800 every month. Mohamed would like to ask for a loan in the amount of SLL 4,000,000 in order to buy additional building materials. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately SLL 342,760. In the future, Mohamed plans to further grow his business, build another house and to educate his children. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: The loan is used to buy building materials.

loans.name: Damira's Group

texts.en: Damira G. is the leader of the group. She is 26 and divorced. She has to bring up her 3-year-old son alone. She makes her living by sewing national costumes: dresses, gowns and trousers. Three years ago, her mother passed this business to her, and out of the profits she has managed to purchase a set (18000 soms). In order to buy fabrics and materials for sewing warm gowns to sell, Damira hopes to get a loan. In the future, she is planning to open her own dressmaking and tailoring establishment and to provide village girls with an appropriate kind of work. Orunbai K., 30, is married. His family has two children in it. The main source of income for the family is from his own business: He bakes national bread and sells flour. His business was started two years ago, after he had been working as a baker in the capital. Out of the business profits, he has managed to obtain a car. In order to purchase 20 bags of flour, Orunbai needs to get a loan. By now he has two bakeries and in the future, he is planning to open one more in the next village. Taalaibek K., 30, is married. He runs his own business of reselling foodstuffs and household goods in his own shop, where his wife also works as a saleswoman. Five years ago, Taalaibek’s parents sold hardware, then they passed the business to him. Out of his profits, he additionally has managed to begin car reselling. The loan purpose is to purchase a car (120,000 soms), taking into account the fact that he has 90,000 soms already. In the future, he is planning to open his own mini market in the village. Altynai S., 24, is married. Together with her husband, who raises money by working as a driver, she is bringing up a daughter. Altynai has a profession as a seamstress. Today, she makes her living by sewing national costumes: dresses, gowns, blouses and so on. She also restores clothes on order. Out of her earnings, she has managed to purchase a calf. The purpose of her loan is to purchase stuff for sewing dresses. In the near future, Altynai wants to dedicate more time to her hobby; that’s why she is planning to open her own sewing shop in the village. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics and materials

loans.name: Mahmad

texts.en: Mahmad A. is 57 years old. He and his wife have raised three children. For five years, Mahmad has been involved in manufacturing wooden doors and window frames. The elder son of Mahmad helps his father in the business. Mahmad is respected and known in the neighborhood as a real master and that allows him to have a clientele. The business is stable, generating the main income for the family. Today, Mahmad needs to purchase input materials like wood, plywood, flake board and other supplies for his business. Also he is planning to improve the working conditions of the business. For this purpose, he requests $2,000. Mahmad thanks all for supporting him and for their trust. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road, and for the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing wood, plywood, flake board and other supplies for making furniture

loans.name: Aiymnisa's Group

texts.en: Aiymnisa M. is the leader of the group. She is 44 and married. Her husband is temporarily unemployed. The couple has four children: The eldest daughter is married; one of the sons works in the capital at a building site; and the rest are still school pupils. Eleven years ago, before marriage, Aiymnisa’s husband used to run his own business. He bred cattle and cultivated corn. By now, the family is preparing for crop cutting (they have planted corn on an area of 0.4 hectares) and they have sent the cattle to grazing land for some period. Soon they'll be back. Out of business profits, they have managed to make house repairs. The family is planning to purchase a horse (25000 soms) and for this purpose, they hope to get a loan. In the future, Aiymnisa wants to arrange her son’s wedding and to build a small house on the grazing land. Saitmurat T., 57, is married. Together with his wife, who keeps house, he has two daughters. Two years ago, he started to run his own business: cultivating plants on his own allotment. By now, the main source of income comes from selling corn, potatoes, carrots and onions. Out of the profits, he has managed to purchase two goats, three sheep and one calf. The loan purpose is to buy 5 tons of onions (5 soms for 1 kg). In the future, Saitmurat is planning to obtain a flat in the center of the city and also to build a shop in the village. Baargul M., 36, is married. She has two children and both of them are school pupils. The family business consists of cattle breeding (now two cows are fattening). Besides that, the head of the family earns additional income by working in the local factory. Their total earnings made it possible to change their house's roof and to purchase two bulls. In order to increase cattle stock, the family is planning to buy a cow. For this purpose, they need to get a loan. In the future, Baargul wants to give a proper education to her children and to develop her family’s business. Halinisa M., 40, is married. Her spouse temporarily works in Russia. She brings up four sons; the eldest is also in Russia, while the rest, except for the youngest one, are schoolboys. The family make its bread by selling vegetables: peppers, tomatoes, garlic, onions and potatoes. Out of the business profits, they have managed to install gates. In order to enlarge their budget, Halinisa wants to purchase four sheep for fattening and breeding. For this purpose, she hopes to get a loan. In the nearer future, she is planning to increase commodity circulation, to develop the business and to give a university education to her children. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a horse

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more vegetables.

loans.name: Gulasal's Group

texts.en:
Gulasal Z. is the leader of the group. she is 47 and married. Her husband, together with 2 sons, raises money by working in Russia. Her daughters are married. Gulasal runs a business by herself: she sells oil (previously, she used to sell up to 100 kg, but now she is selling about 500 kg). Out of their profits, the family has managed to change their car to a minibus. The loan purpose is to buy more oil to increase working capital. In the future, she is planning to open her own trade outlet and to develop her business.

Salimahon N., 52, is married. Her big family has seven children (1 son, 6 daughters, all of them are married, except twins girls), the son works in Russia. Salimahon is a pensioner. Her husband is a driver by profession. Together, the couple is cultivating potatoes and onions. By now they have managed to arrange their children's weddings and to purchase cattle. The loan purpose is to buy a refrigerator. In future the family is planning to increase cattle stock.

Uulbu B. is the treasurer of the group. She is 52 and married. Her spouse raises money by goods transportation. She herself earns additionally by working as a librarian. They are also engaged in cattle breeding. The couple has 6 sons, two of them are in Russia, another two-in Kazakhstan, and the youngest are schoolboys. Out of total profits they have managed to obtain a car, to arrange their sons’ weddings and to purchase sheep. The loan purpose is to buy a refrigerator. In the future, Uulbu wants to build a house.

Gulnura E., 31, is married. Her spouse is an employee of the Criminal Investigation Department. The couple brings up 2 children. Gulnura earns money by sewing children's bedding. Due to 10 years of working hard, she has managed to obtain 2 sewing-machines. The loan purpose is to purchase items for sewing. In the future, she is planning to build or to buy a house.

Jaanbu S., 50, is married. Her husband is a driver. The couple has 4 children, the elder son and the daughter work in Russia. The family runs their own business: they cultivate agricultural production. During 20 years of working, they have managed to purchase 2 cows and a car. The loan purpose is to obtain household appliances. In future Jaanbu is planning to organize her son’s wedding. 

Nasibahon E., 51, is married. Her spouse raises money by goods transportation. In winter he transports coal, in summer, hardware. The couple has 5 children: the daughters are married, and the sons work in Russia. Due to 5 years of working, the family has managed to obtain a truck. The loan purpose is to purchase household appliances. In the future, Nasibahon is planning to arrange her sons’ weddings and to buy a new car.

A. U. Chyngyz, 18, a bachelor.
